_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental release prevention and emergency response policy of this facility:   This facility is newly constructed (1996) and was designed and built to conform to all codes, specitications, and applicable regulations that were in place in 1996, both state and federal.  Hopefully through continued plant maintainence and employee training, an accidental release will not occur.  If, however, an accidental release should occur it is our policy to notify the Sutherland Community Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.

Facility description and the regulated substance handled:     This facility is a fertilizer plant and is operated as such by the local agricultural cooperative.  The facility handles annhydrous ammonia for use as fertilizer by its farmer members.  The plant has permanent anhydrous ammonia storage capacity of 30,000 gallons which puts the plant into the regulated catagory.  Along with the permanent storage tank and associated valves, piping, etc.  We use nurse tanks and applicators for our farmers to transport and inject the ammonia into the ground.

Worst case scenario:    Our worst case scenario would be if the 30,000 gallon tank was filled to allowable capacity and for some reason would rupture.  This could conceivably result in the release of 160,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  According to EPA look-up tables the distance to the endpoint is 6.9 miles where in this rural enviroment 1548 people reside.

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention program:    This facility complies with all "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" (ANSI K6 1.1) guidelines published by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).  In addition to these standards it is our policy to continually maintain and update our equiptment to all current state and federal anhydrous ammonia handling guidelines.  We also maintain a continuing education and safety education program for all empl

oyees inside and out.

Five-year Accident History:    We have never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

Emergency Response Program:    In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia plant, it is a policy to notify the Sutherland Community Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.  We have discussed this policy sith the fire department and we invite them to tour our facility on an annual basis to familiarize them with our facility in the event of an emergency.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:   None at this time.
